item.title: Jared Kushner’s Role Is Tested as Russia Case Grows
item.media:description: President Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser, Jared Kushner, at a news conference this month at the White House.
item.description: It is unclear how Jared Kushner’s high-profile woes will affect his hard-won partnership with his father-in-law, perhaps the most stable in an often unstable White House.
item.dc:creator: GLENN THRUSH, MAGGIE HABERMAN and SHARON LaFRANIERE

item.title: Reported Talks by Jared Kushner With Russia Would Be ‘Good Thing,’ Trump Official Says
item.media:description: President Trump and Melania Trump arriving at the White House on Saturday night after a nine-day overseas trip.
item.description: John F. Kelly, the homeland security secretary, played down reports of a back channel. The president, meanwhile, resumed using Twitter as a weapon.
item.dc:creator: MATT FLEGENHEIMER and PETER BAKER

item.title: News Analysis: Melania Trump, in Supporting Role, Shows Subdued Star Power on Trip
item.media:description: Melania Trump at the Western Wall in Jerusalem last week.
item.description: Mrs. Trump’s travels with the president were something of a coming-out party, which may offer clues to what kind of first lady she could become.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Critic's Notebook: Melania Trump on Display, Dressed in Ambivalence and Armor
item.media:description: Mrs. Trump wore a black lace sheath dress by Dolce & Gabbana with a matching veil to meet the pope. Some critics wondered why the first lady chose to cover her head at the Vatican but not in Saudi Arabia, where most Muslim women wear headscarves.
item.description: Nine days, five countries, and more than a dozen outfits: the first lady makes a statement abroad.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA FRIEDMAN

item.title: Sidebar: A Constitutional Puzzle: Can the President Be Indicted?
item.media:description: President Trump boarding Marine One on the South Lawn of the White House this month. Legal experts disagree about whether the Constitution allows for a president to be indicted.
item.description: The Constitution includes detailed instructions for impeachment. But there’s no clear answer on whether a president may be criminally prosecuted.
item.dc:creator: ADAM LIPTAK

item.title: North Korean Tests Add Urgency for U.S. to Fix Defense Flaws
item.media:description: The medium-range strategic ballistic missile Pukguksong-2, shown in this undated image, was tested recently at an undisclosed location in North Korea. The North has successfully tested solid-fueled missiles four times.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The North has recently test-fired missiles based on a technology that would give the United States little warning of an attack. And they seem to work.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: North Korea Fires Missile That Lands in Sea Between Korea and Japan
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The apparent test of a ballistic missile that landed near Japan comes a week after the test of another ballistic missile.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Emmanuel Macron Challenges Putin on Syria and Gay Rights
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, left, welcoming his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, on Monday at Versailles, near Paris.
item.media:credit: Geoffroy Van Der Hasselt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: France’s newly elected president said that the use of chemical weapons in Syria was a “red line,” and that the punishment of gay men in Chechnya would be monitored.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: 52 Places to Go: A Bird’s Eye View in Laikipia
item.description: Here are three ways to spy wildlife, large and small, in the Laikipia region of Kenya.

item.title: Your Daily Mini Crossword
item.description: Solve a bite-size crossword in just a few minutes.

item.title: War Hero’s Family Suing in Its Decades-Long Fight to Identify Remains
item.media:description: The American Cemetery in Manila. The family of Alexander Nininger, who was killed in World War II, says his remains are buried there.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: The family of Alexander Nininger, the first Medal of Honor recipient in World War II, has contended for decades that he is buried in Manila as an “unknown.”
item.dc:creator: DAVE PHILIPPS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A Guide to Staying on Top of Your Student Loan
item.media:description: Federal student loan rates will rise for the 2017-18 academic year.
item.description: Our best guidance for families and students trying to figure out the best strategies for managing college debt.
item.dc:creator: ANNA DUBENKO

item.title: Hackers Hide Cyberattacks in Social Media Posts
item.media:description: Jay Kaplan, left, and Mark Kuhr, the founders of Synack, a cybersecurity company. “The problem is pervasive,” Mr. Kaplan said.
item.description: A recent attack on the accounts of Defense Department employees suggests how easily people can be duped into clicking on dangerous links.
item.dc:creator: SHEERA FRENKEL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: The ‘Bronx Tale’ Strategy: Win Suburban Love, Not Broadway Prestige
item.media:description: Nick Cordero, left, as Sonny and Hudson Loverro as the young Calogero in the musical “A Bronx Tale,” at the Longacre Theater.
item.description: The musical received no Tony nominations. But nostalgia and smart marketing are filling the seats with the “Jersey Boys” demographic.
item.dc:creator: SOPAN DEB

item.title: Christian-Backed School Teaches Scions of the Elite in Atheist North Korea
item.media:description: Students at the Pyongyang University of Science and Technology in 2011. The North Korean school is staffed with volunteer Christian professors, many of them American.
item.description: In a country that bans religion, the school educates a crop of handpicked students — and perhaps gives the government some leverage with Washington.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Pyongyang University of Science and Technology

item.title: Three Men Stood Up to Anti-Muslim Attack. Two Paid With Their Lives.
item.media:description: Coco Douglas, 8, on Saturday at a memorial in Portland, Ore., for two men who were killed when they confronted a man yelling anti-Muslim insults at two women on a commuter train.
item.description: The victims in Friday’s attack were an Army veteran, a recent college graduate and a poet who spoke out against anti-Muslim prejudice.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: The Coat of Arms Said ‘Integrity.’ Now It Says ‘Trump.’
item.media:description: The crest, right, that President Trump displays at his American properties is a coat of arms, left, that British authorities granted to another family.
item.description: The emblem used by the Trump Organization in the United States had to be changed in Britain, since it belongs to another family.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM

item.title: Afloat on the Erie Canal: Sonar Gear, Ferris Wheel Parts and Beer Tanks
item.media:description: Twelve enormous beer tanks, headed to the Genesee Beer Company in Rochester, are among the oversize cargo populating the Erie Canal.
item.media:credit: Nathaniel Brooks for The New York Times
item.description: The canal, long relegated as a recreational byway, has had a rebound in commercial shipping for odd and oversize cargo.
item.dc:creator: JESSE McKINLEY

item.title: On Memorial Day, Trump Pays Tribute to Fallen Troops
item.media:description: President Trump laid a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Solider at Arlington National Cemetery, in Arlington, Va., on Monday, to mark Memorial Day.
item.description: At a solemn ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery, President Trump praised those “who died in war so we could live in peace.”
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: U.K. Is Investigating Missed Signals Over Manchester Bomber
item.media:description: Police officers outside Didsbury Mosque in Manchester, England, last week. At least two congregants from the mosque reported Salman Abedi, the assailant in the Manchester Arena bombing that left 22 dead, to the authorities two years ago, a law enforcement official confirmed.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The British domestic intelligence agency will focus on why, despite repeated warnings from the public, agents decided that the bomber, Salman Abedi, posed no threat.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Merkel, After Discordant G-7 Meeting, Is Looking Past Trump
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany in Munich on Sunday. “The times in which we could rely fully on others, they are somewhat over,” she said.
item.description: After President Trump declined to endorse NATO’s doctrine of collective defense and the Paris climate pact, the German leader said Europe should “take our fate into our own hands.”
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Philippine Forces Struggle to Retake City Held by Islamist Militants
item.media:description: A Philippine Air Force helicopter launching a rocket in Marawi on Monday. Government troops have cleared about half of the city of militants.
item.description: An official called on civilians to help the military clear Marawi, a city in the south, of insurgents from ISIS-linked groups who are proving difficult to dislodge.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Takuma Sato Narrowly Wins the Indianapolis 500 on a Day of Crashes
item.media:description: Takuma Sato of Japan drenching himself with milk, an Indianapolis 500 tradition, after winning the 101st running of the race on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Mark J. Rebilas/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.description: Sato, the first champion from Japan, is a 40-year-old former Formula One driver who has just one other victory in IndyCar racing.
item.dc:creator: JERRY GARRETT

item.title: Tiger Woods Is Charged in Florida for Driving Under the Influence
item.media:description: The mug shot of Tiger Woods after he was taken into custody in Jupiter, Fla., early Monday morning.
item.description: Woods, 41, who has won 14 major championships but has been troubled by health problems in recent years, was taken into custody at 3 a.m. in Jupiter, Fla.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: After Technical Chaos, British Airways Looks to Restore Schedule
item.media:description: Passengers waiting to check in at Heathrow Airport near London on Sunday. British Airways was still grappling on Monday with the impact of a major technical failure over the weekend.
item.description: The airline said it was running most flights as normal, but the weekend disruption has resulted in tense scenes at London’s two biggest airports in particular.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Francesco Totti Leaves the Field, and Romans Weep for a Living Monument
item.media:description: Fans of A.S. Roma watching Francesco Totti’s final game on Sunday. Many took his departure hard.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: It’s been a rough decade for Rome. Jobs have left and garbage piles up in the streets. The latest kick in the gut? Francesco Totti has left the soccer pitch.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: China Charges Activist From Taiwan With ‘Subverting State Power’
item.media:description: Lee Ching-yu holding a photo of her husband, the rights advocate Lee Ming-cheh, at a news conference in Taipei, Taiwan, in March.
item.description: The mainland authorities have never leveled that charge against someone from Taiwan before, and his formal arrest adds a new strain to tensions between Beijing and Taipei.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The Motive in a Manhattan Shooting? The Statue of Liberty
item.media:description: Passengers aboard a boat operated by the Hop-On Hop-Off Liberty Cruise, a boat that does not dock at Liberty Island.
item.media:credit: Alex Wroblewski for The New York Times
item.description: An unlikely turf battle at the bottom of Manhattan is being fought over the Statue of Liberty. There have been several assaults and most recently a shooting.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and NATE SCHWEBER

item.title: A Russian Businessman’s Road From Siberia to Success
item.media:description: Andrei Trubnikov, the founder of Natura Siberica, in the company’s offices in Moscow surrounded by bottles and beauty products he has bought on his travels for inspiration and comparison for packaging.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: A cosmetics company is a rare bright spot for a Russian economy that has been languishing in recent years.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: John Severson, Surfer Who Illustrated Allure of Waves, Dies at 83
item.media:description: John Severson working at San Onofre State Beach outside San Clemente, Calif., in 1959.
item.description: Mr. Severson founded Surfer magazine in 1962 and created paintings, films and photographs depicting the surfing lifestyle.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Navy Parachutist Dies During Demonstration Over Jersey City
item.media:description: An investigator held a bag of evidence as officials looked into the death Sunday of a Leap Frogs parachutist whose name was not immediately released.
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.description: The parachutist, a member of the elite Leap Frogs team, plunged into the Hudson River as hundreds watched from Liberty State Park.
item.dc:creator: SARAH MASLIN NIR and NIKITA STEWART

item.title: By the Book: Al Franken: By the Book
item.media:description: Al Franken
item.description: The author of “Al Franken: Giant of the Senate” has at least one Congressional Research Service report on his night stand. “But it’s under Carl Reiner’s book on ‘The Dick Van Dyke Show.’”

item.title: How the Clothes Make the First Lady
item.media:credit: Left to right, Wong Maye-E/Associated Press; Doug Mills/The New York Times; Pool photo by Dominic Lipinski
item.description: Some criticize writing about the fashion statements of public figures like Melania Trump. But sartorial choices tell us a lot about a person.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA FRIEDMAN

item.title: Letter of Recommendation: Letter of Recommendation: ‘Terrace House’
item.media:description: A reality show so punishingly mundane it becomes beautiful.
item.description: A reality show so punishingly mundane that it becomes beautiful.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW RIDKER
